urn:contentItem:5DHP-YHK1-F03R-N0KP-00000-00Best Cloud Storage Providers for 20142014-11-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:20:51ZLexisNexisBest Cloud Storage Providers for 2014Heather Catalano

Nov 04, 2014 (The Simple Dollar:http://www.thesimpledollar.com/ Delivered by Newstex)
Over the past 20 years, data has moved out of your hard drive and into the cloud. The world is becoming more and more mobile without compromising accessibility. Luckily, technology has quickly advanced to accommodate our newfound lifestyles.


Cloud storage providers enable individuals and businesses to easily transfer files to secure networks in order to free up device space while allowing for seamless collaboration between multiple parties.
This article is part of a series in which The Simple Dollar is doing some deep dive research into money saving tools that can help your business thrive.
In this article, I'll discuss the what, why, and how of cloud storage for businesses. The 'when' is clear: If you're not utilizing the cloud, the time is now. We'll also explore the best of the best cloud storage providers for business in specific arenas, as well as The Simple Dollar's Top Picks based on overall performance.
The Simple Dollar's Overall Top Picks
The overall ranking to determine the top three best cloud storage providers for business was based on the above categories, as well as a scoring system that considered their ranking as either the #1 or #2 pick within each category (SugarSync and Carbonite tied for first, so they were listed alphabetically):
Carbonite[1] SugarSync[2] Adrive[3] Box
Make sure you visit the above sections that describe the key components of cloud storage for business. Cloud storage, like many business solutions, is not a one-size-fits-all product.
What Is the Cloud?
Many, if not all of you, are cloud computing on a regular basis. If you've ever uploaded a photo to a social network, are using a smartphone with data backed up, or accessed Google Drive or Dropbox, you've been an active participant.
Think of the cloud as a virtual flash drive. You contract a designated amount of space (for some paid services, that means unlimited space), upload files that are storing your data, and they're seamlessly transferred to the cloud.
The cloud itself is not in the sky, but rather in physical locations throughout the world stored on multiple, secure servers. Clouds are typically managed and owned by hosting companies referred to here as providers. Some providers use a trusted third-party hosting company like Google. We'll discuss the benefits of server-owned solutions later in this post.
Cloud Storage for Business
If you have a business and aren't using cloud storage, it's time to start! Cloud storage can make your workforce more efficient and productive, while backing up and securing your valuable data. Making sure you choose the right storage provider for you and your company is key to your success.
With the shift to virtual and accessible storage, businesses now have the ability to pay for the amount of storage they need at a competitive rate without overinvesting in device memory, or worse, having to arm their employees with easily misplaced flash drives.
The sharing and editing capabilities within the cloud allow for collaboration without the administrative burden and likelihood of outdated file updating that comes with emailing. More importantly, this collaboration can be done in real time, which greatly expedites the process. If time isn't a resource you could benefit from having more of, then please share your secrets with the rest of us!
The truth is, storing large amounts of data outside of the cloud is no longer cost effective, efficient, nor safe for your business. Let's explore the main features the best online storage providers are offering today so you can get a better idea of which solution is the right fit for you and your soon-to-be growing business.
Compatibility
As businesses move toward a BYOD (Bring Your Own Device) market to cut overhead costs and allow their employees freedom to choose the device that works best for them, you'll be surprised by the variety that ends up on the table. If you're going to have flexibility in the devices your employees will utilize, it's important to mirror that flexibility in your cloud storage.
So, as you consider a new cloud storage provider, ask yourself: Are you primarily a Windows or Mac user? Does your sales force use iPhones, Androids, BlackBerry phones, or a mix?
The big tech players have all created platforms of their own cloud storage: Windows with their new OneDrive and Mac's iCloud. However, that doesn't mean you should discredit or even hesitate to lean toward others like SugarSync and Bitcasa.
Oftentimes, it's best to go with the provider whose main focus is the solution you're seeking. You'll have a lot more concentrated resources and development around the topic at hand.
The Simple Dollar's Top Cloud Storage Picks for Compatibility:
SugarSync[4]: compatible with Windows, Mac, Android, iOS, BlackBerry, and Windows Phone Bitcasa: compatible with Windows, Mac, Linux, Android, iOS, and Windows Phone
These providers are among the few that have committed to an expansive portfolio of compatible platforms. Unless if you already do, or plan, to have company provided devices for both laptops or cellphones make sure to go with a diverse compatibility provider.
Storage Amounts
You no longer have to be married to a finite amount of storage. Most cloud storage plans can be increased, decreased, even cancelled if needed. However, don't lose sight of the fact that if (when!) your business grows exponentially, you may want the capability of unlimited storage, something that's not available with all providers' plans.
The Simple Dollar's Top Picks for Cloud Storage Amounts:
Adrive[5] Carbonite[6]
Both Adrive and Carbonite offer competitive pricing, especially at the annual rate, and have the option for unlimited storage. If you sign up for Adrive's 200TB 3-year contract you'll be paying less than $50/month. To put in perspective, that's over 3 million hours of music, 800 days of video, and 62 million photos.
File Upload Limitations
As simple as transferring data to the cloud can be, it does come with some restrictions depending on the provider and the level of service you've chosen.
The Simple Dollar's Top Picks for Cloud Storage File Uploads:
Carbonite[7] OpenDrive
Both of these providers come without file upload size restrictions, and were specifically chosen as the best because they also offer unlimited storage. Make sure you check the maximum storage with your provider before you get excited about the size of file you can upload.
If you move forward with Carbonite, keep in mind that while they will allow you to upload a file of any size, those that are more than 4GB need to be uploaded manually.
Sharing Capabilities
Sharing is a key component in the success of your business. Unless you're a business of one, plan to never expand, and don't want to have easy, seamless communication with colleagues, the ability to share files should always be included in your cloud storage decision-making process.
The Simple Dollar's Top Picks for Cloud Storage Sharing:
SugarSync[8] Box
With SugarSync, you can share individual files or entire folders with any other team member or across entire teams with just a few clicks. You also have the ability to limit permissions on specific files or folders, controlling access so it's either 'read-only' or 'can edit.' On top of that, you can create a public link and share it with anyone without the need for them to register for the service. This feature alone can save you an infinite amount of email space since you no longer have to attach all those pesky files.
Box also allows you to share links accompanied by passwords, expiration dates, and restricted download access. You can create folders for group projects and quickly assign access limitations to each collaborator with co-ownership, editing, or view-only rights.
Collaboration
Just like sharing, collaboration is necessary for your business to thrive. You no longer have to wonder if you have your hands on the latest version of a document since, with cloud storage, multiple people can access a file simultaneously and everyone will always get the latest version. If you've ever accidentally worked on an older document, you probably felt that it compromised your time and valuable resources!
As workforces become more and more mobile, the ability to collaborate within a virtual space is critical.
The Simple Dollar's Top Picks for Cloud Storage for Collaboration:
ZipCloud[9] JustCloud[10]
Both ZipCloud and JustCloud Business Plans allow for unlimited users, unlimited devices, easy file-sharing, and synced, real-time file updates. With ZipCloud, you can also allocate the amount of storage space available to each user, keeping your entire program flexible. With JustCloud, you can create admin control panels and file-sharing access permissions.
Accessibility
One of the biggest benefits of cloud storage is the infinite accessibility when you and your employees are online. You can retrieve, share, and edit files from anywhere in the world.
But will you always have Internet access? Many cloud storage providers offer syncing capabilities that grant you access to specific files or folders from your cloud even when you're offline. This is especially helpful if your workforce is not always in a dedicated office, as Wi-Fi-only tablets, spotty mobile reception, and means of transportation are not guaranteed to connect you to the World Wide Web.
The Simple Dollar's Top Picks for Cloud Storage Accessibility:
SugarSync[11] Box
Both of these providers allow you to sync entire folders to be available offline rather than individual files. When you reconnect with the cloud, any files that were edited will be automatically updated. If you're adding files to one of the synced folders in Box, you will need to click 'Update All' to ensure you have offline access to the new ones as well.
Security
Security is a hot topic for cloud-based storage. You need to trust your provider, so make sure to conduct some research and understand the functions of specific features, like syncing and archiving, before handing your files over.
For example, Dropbox's sync feature allows for multiple parties to sync to the same folder, if one of the parties removes that file from the folder it will be removed on everyone's computer. This is an intentional feature to keep everyone's files/folders as up-to-date as possible; however, can cause quite a scare if the delete was done on accident. Have no fear though, Dropbox, as well as many other providers, keep backups of all files for 30 days.
As a measure of security, the most common providers like Google Drive and previously mentioned Dropbox use two-step authentication, which is great. What's even better are the additional security features offered by our top-pick providers.
The Simple Dollar's Top Picks for Cloud Storage Security:
Carbonite[12] Box
These features include, but are not limited to, the following:
Servers are owned and maintained by the provider rather than a third party, limiting the potential for hacking or surveillance. The ability to delete files from your computer remotely in the event it is lost or stolen. All files are encrypted directly by the provider rather than a third party. The user has the ability to limit specific folder permissions when sharing. All files are geo-redundantly stored, meaning they are housed in multiple physical locations in the event that there is damage at one of the storage centers.
HIPAA Compliance Security
Depending on the level of complexity and regulations in your industry, you may need to go with a more tightly compliant provider. If your company requires compliance with the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA), make sure you research your options before moving forward with any provider.
The Simple Dollar's Top Picks for Cloud Storage With HIPAA Compliance:
Carbonite[13] Egnyte
Both platforms are entirely built to be compliant with HIPAA regulations and both have up-to-date HIPAA Business Associate Agreements.
Free Cloud Storage
Few things in life are more appealing than the term 'free.' Don't forget that free services come with limitations and, when it comes to your business, you want anything but to be limited. However, if you're a startup and are looking for ways to cut those initial overhead fees, a free service and the ability to increase storage is likely your best bet.
The Simple Dollar's Top Picks for Free Cloud Storage:
Adrive[14] GoogleDrive
Adrive offers an impressive 50GB of free storage within their cloud. The only cost you'll pay is having to deal with ads. Google Drive provides 15GB of free cloud storage.
One thing I do not recommend is using multiple free services in order to expand your cloud storage. While there are emerging providers like Odrive, a consumer-based application that can link your free storage solutions like Google Drive, Dropbox, and OneDrive, you run the risk of mitigating any cost benefits with the administrative burden of organizing and accessing multiple accounts on a regular basis.
Rather than linking these multiple solutions, you should upgrade your service with the same provider or find one that aligns with your business more closely in order to maintain consistency.
Methodology
Based on primary purpose of this article being money saving tips for your business we have focused solely on SaaS (Software as a Service) providers rather than IaaS (Infrastructure as a Service) or PaaS (Platform as a Service) providers, which can come with a heftier price tag due to the amount of initial resources.
SaaS providers typically eliminate the need for technical staff and reduce the cost of licensing. The providers manage the infrastructure and platforms that run on the application and charge a subscription fee for its use. This allows pricing to be scalable depending on the number of users and amount of storage needed.
I narrowed down the most reputable, based on a combination of longevity of service existence, BBB ratings, features and customer reviews, SaaS providers and then further filtered those that did not have a business plan out of the mix. From the remaining twenty providers I created a chart ranking them on specifics within the categories listed above (i.e. compatibility, storage amounts, file upload limitations, etc.) to determine the best of the best.
Conclusion
The cloud storage realm is rapidly growing and ever changing. Many providers offer competitor comparisons on their websites, but make sure you take these with a grain of salt as there are many different components to take into consideration before moving forward with this decision for your company.
During my research I found the history of the development of cloud storage to be fascinating. I was pleasantly surprised how smaller companies, like SugarSync[15], have pivoted to remain competitive with powerhouses like Dropbox by targeting and improving their business sector services over individual, free services.
The comparison within this article, based on the selected criteria, should give you a solid place to start your journey in selecting the best cloud storage. If you have experience with other providers that have been successful for your business please share below! We will continue to revisit these suggestions and update as new features and potential players emerge.

urn:contentItem:5MCT-DNG1-JC8V-44GS-00000-00BEST DIGITAL BANKS 2016;Banking On Technology To Serve Customers2016-09-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:20:51ZLexisNexisCOVER STORYPg. 12BEST DIGITAL BANKS 2016Banking On Technology To Serve CustomersGilly Wright

By aping technology firms, banks that simplify solutions and focus upon the customer experience will be the ones that survive.

Technology lets banks make banking simpler for consumers and, by following the lead set by top technology companies and agile start-ups, banks are learning how to tap into customer behavior and design more appealing online experiences.

Banks are embracing the practices of the tech firms that know how to solve complex problems instead of creating them. Herber De Ruijter, head of digital strategy at Intellect Global Transaction Banking (iGTB), says "simplexity"-making highly complex systems usable with simple interfaces-is a key trend as banks and corporations embrace digital disruption to serve retail customers.

"As a consumer you won't even notice a lot of these innovations," he explains. "However, a couple of great ones are changing the way we do business with our banks: [services providing] easy-to-understand and actionable advice on retirement; crowdfunding and lending fintechs, such as Kabbage, allowing instant access to capital; mobile payment wallets, as a first step to an almost cashless world; and Uber-where you just don't pay at all [payment happens seamlessly in the background]."

It's not just better products or rates that make such companies popular: They make business transactions smooth and easy. "What all these disrupters have in common is that they leverage technology, machine learning and artificial intelligence to create frictionless origination and a self-service experience," continues De Ruijter. "Technology combined with very refined user experiences is the answer when it comes to simplicity, which drives adoption."

Banks are still in the diagnostic phase as they try to understand the way big tech companies operate so that, over time, they can mirror them. "The biggest threats don't come from the biggest banks but from the biggest tech companies," continues Ruijter. "They have the best cards. Banks either will [transform] or already are transforming themselves into tech companies. Look at Goldman Sachs, which actively contributes to open-source projects, shares its assets based on current technologies-like Web component libraries-with the world, and currently employs 10,000 engineers spread out over 44 offices in 15 countries."

New business models include aggregator bank initiatives, such as Starling, Simple and Atom, which develop financial products by bundling the banking services of others. "These initiatives today compete on superior user experience and premium customer service-which people love," states De Ruijter.

Another option for banks is to partner to co-create, co-design or buy innovations. "At iGTB, we do quite a lot of projects where customers outsource parts of their digital innovation to us, intending to let that innovation come back into the bank. You see a lot of interest in our lean engineering and user-centric design principles, and their success encourages banks to familiarize themselves with such approaches."

Although this is clearly great for those who are late in the game or have time-to-market problems, De Ruijter believes many smaller banks will survive only by bundling white-label solutions designed by others and combining these with premium products they carry themselves.

BIG DATA, BIG REWARDS

Jeremy Taylor, strategy owner for capital markets at GFT, a fintech firm, sees opportunities for both challenger banks and smaller banks. "If you are a Tier 2 regional bank, you've got an opportunity to leapfrog some of the big boys, because top-tier banks are encumbered with balance sheets that are stodgy and they've got capital costs now with Basel III, so they are all trying to figure out complex tech and data issues-and many are divesting themselves of products, clients and countries because of the high cost of regulations and capital."

In July, GFT's International Survey of Experts on Digital Banking revealed that banks were unhappy with skills shortfalls when dealing with data. Reliable data offers substantial upside potential, by helping banks personalize marketing, analyzing patterns with increasing detail and sophistication. Taylor advises banks to have a roadmap to manage resources sensibly rather than in spikes, as banks are constantly going in and out of the contract market. "The problem has been 30 years in the making," he says. "It's part of a wider strategy of simplification that they need to develop. In the last two to five years there has been a wake-up call that this is actually a brake on their businesses and could cause them data compliance problems because half of the data compliance requirements are shoved down the priority list."

THIRD-PARTY OPPORTUNITIES

Bundled products developed by banks and combined with those of third parties, distributed through digital channels and attached to their brand, is, according to De Ruijter, still a strong proposition: "Those products will constantly be refined through analytics, testing and other similar developments mirroring those we have seen in retail." He adds, "The technologies have already existed for many years; the challenge for banks now is ascertaining how to extract useful information from the tons of data they hold."

De Ruijter says banks at the forefront will personalize these products, tailoring them to segments they are targeting, or will develop products specifically for underserved markets, such as small and medium-size enterprises. "The application programming interface (API) economy will drive more mass-customized offerings that align with the needs of various customer segments, particularly those that are currently underserved," he says. "Out of the strategic leveraging of data will come more-advanced products-for example, ones that are in-context [interaction customers have with the bank], or consumption-based, or dynamically priced."

Singapore's Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation (OCBC Bank), for example, recently opened up its API's to third-party developers to create a "data social network" that facilitates free flow of certain non-customer data in a secure manner for the benefit of third parties and the community as a whole.

In Europe, the Payment Services Directive 2 (PSD2) will allow a more level playing field for third-party payment processors. Some banks have been running scared at the thought of further disintermediation, but many see it, Taylor says, as an opportunity to work with Internet companies to develop apps and e-service bundles that give them an edge.

Some fintechs focused on payments are helping banks build bridges between social media and traditional banking payment networks. "The crossover between banking payment networks and social media networks is a huge opportunity," explains Taylor. "We all use social media, and it just makes sense to combine that with paying bills, sending money to relatives for birthday presents, etc." Websites offer buttons for various easy, one-click payments methods-Paypal, credit card. "If you are a bank, you want your bank's button to be on all these online retail outlets," Taylor adds. "Although PSD2 opens up banks' networks to new entrants, if they do it right, they can have their button on every single website."

CREATING NEW MARKETS

Repackaging and creating new experiences on smartphones gives banks international opportunities to find new customers. In Africa and Asia, technology is enabling banks to acquire and serve consumers in markets formerly unassailable.

Chris de Bruin, global head of retail products and digital at Standard Chartered, says the digital agenda is a response to growing demand for convenience and choice. "People are looking to conduct more activities digitally, where they do not have to spend time traveling to a branch and queueing for services," he says. "We offer secure banking services through digital channels so our customers can do their banking anytime and anywhere they like, and this helps us reach more clients, regardless of where they are."

Standard Chartered has rolled out a new mobile and online banking platform in eight African countries-Botswana, Ghana, Kenya, Nigeria, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe-reaching one million retail clients, according to De Bruin. Using a smartphone, tablet or laptop, clients can check balances, transfer money and pay bills securely. "Their mobile device is, in effect, a bank at their fingertips," he says.

Another example is Retail Workbench, which Standard Chartered rolled out in nine countries-Korea, Singapore, India, Malaysia, Bangladesh, the UAE, Kenya, Nigeria and Pakistan. "The digital 'bank in an iPad' sales-and-service tool is seamlessly integrated with the bank's back-end infrastructure, so our staff can meet clients in a location of their choice, be it their office or favorite coffee house," De Bruin explains. "Our staff can then help them open an account, or approve loans or issue credit cards, making banking services fast, simple and completely paperless."

Standard Chartered's network across more than 30 markets in Asia, Africa and the Middle East provides the bank rich veins of feedback from various markets. "As a result, we build once for many," says De Bruin, "focusing on building capability in the most global and standardized way as possible-so it is very portable, yet allows for localization."

Although valuable innovations come from both developing and developed markets, the regulatory environments in India and China, De Bruin says, have enabled multiple innovative digital-banking solutions that could potentially be exported to other markets.

"Highly digital Korea has been a test bed for innovation, such as the Retail Workbench," De Bruin says. "We introduced the new technology there in 2014, and we will roll it out in 18 markets by end of 2017. Touch-login biometric technology-which we first introduced in Singapore this year-will be rolled out to nearly 5.5 million clients in 16 markets across Asia, Africa and the Middle East by end of the year."

This ability to behave like agile technology firms has meant banks are adopting an Amazon-like mind-set to drive up-sell and cross-sell options. "Instead of being 'places where people go to bank,' banks will evolve into 'brands that clients prefer to use for financial transactions,'" states De Bruin.

"Even given various privacy restrictions, banks have access to a profusion of real-time and quite actionable data, which will allow them to give their customers a 'Best Next Action' or 'Best Next Offer' (tailored to their needs and preferences). The more complex the type of financial product, the higher my expectation is that my bank is my trusted adviser, and the higher the adoption rate," concludes De Ruijter. "Customers' trust in banks is still very strong."

Jun 30, 2017( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) With the first half of 2017 drawing to a close, it is time to look back at what worked in the investment world. Leveraged ETFs sure deserve a mention here given how copiously they give returns to investors (read: Trump Slump to Oil Slide: Top ETF Stories of First-Half 2017[1]).The period took dramatic turns from the Trump rally on hopes of fiscal reflation to uncertainty over his policy uncertainty, oil price relief to oil price slump and finally the emergence of international economies.On a year-to-date basis (as of June 29, 2017), the S...00-based ETF SPY[2] has gained about 9%, the Dow Jones-based ETF DIA[3] has advanced 8.9% while the Nasdaq 100-based QQQ[4] has rallied around 16.7%. Needless to say, such stellar gains have had a significant impact on the leveraged ETFs.These ETFs provide multiple times exposure to the performance of the underlying index. These funds employ various investment strategies such as use of swaps, futures contracts and other derivative instruments to accomplish their objectives.Since most of these ETFs seek to attain their goals on a daily basis, their performance could vary significantly over a longer period when compared to the short period due to their compounding effect.Still, the space remains a hot area for investors looking for high returns in a short time.

They must be interested to know about the top-leveraged ETF performers of the first half of 2017.A Glance at the ToppersDirexion Daily S...iotech Bull 3X ETF LABU[5] - Up 109.8% YTDThis segment also caught investors' attention in the first half. Easing outrage against the price gouging issue, President Trump's pledges to reduce FDA regulations and remove taxes and fees on pharmaceutical and medical-device manufacturers favored the space (read: Forget Big Tech, Biotech ETFs are Soaring Higher[6]).This has led to 109.8% gains for LABU so far this year (as of June 29, 2017). The fund looks to offer three times the performance of the S...iotechnology Select Industry Index.Direxion Daily South Korea Bull 3X ETF KORU[7] - Up 88.9% YTDSouth Korea underwent a presidential election in the first half. Moon Jae-In, who was elected on May 9, 2017, announced an 11.2 trillion won(about $10 billion) fiscal stimulus package in early June. The government estimates that 'the extra spending[8] will boost economic growth by 0.2 percentage point this year, which may raise its 2017 outlook from current 2.6%' (read: South Korea ETFs in Focus on $10 Billion Stimulus[9]).Plus, the ripple effect of the tech rally boosted the fund in the first half. The fund offers 300% of the performance of the MSCI Korea 25/50 Index.Direxion Daily CSI China Internet Bull 2X Shares CWEB[10] - Up 81.3% YTDThe first half of 2017 was all about the tech rally worldwide. Solid earnings and increasing euphoria on digitalization and e-commerce made the space lucrative. The fund offers twice (2x) the leveraged exposure to the Chinese Internet market by tracking the CSI Overseas China Internet Index(read: 5 Best Performing Leveraged ETFs of May[11]).Direxion Daily Hmbldrs...ls Bull 3X ETF NAIL[12] - Up 71.5% YTDThe housing sector has been in good shape lately. If we go by the latest data points, new home sales rebounded in May[13] after a downbeat April. Existing home sales for the month of May also increased to the third highest monthly level[14] in a decade. Favorable mortgage rates and a solid labor market helped the sector to put up a decent show. The fund tracks 300% of the performance of the Dow Jones U.S. Select Home Construction Index. (read: Surprise ETF Winners Post Fed Hike[15]).Direxion Daily MSCI India Bull 3x ETF INDL[16] - Up 62.3% YTDIndia ETFs gave a stellar show in the first half on economic optimism. Decent GDP data defying demonetization, the victory of the pro-growth prime minister's party in some state elections, implementation of goods-and-services tax or GST from July, and a weaker greenback drove Indian stocks. Dear readers,Looking at stock markets it is easy to forget that we are in the middle of a pandemic. Listings in the first half of the year h...

Dear readers,

Looking at stock markets it is easy to forget that we are in the middle of a pandemic. Listings in the first half of the year have raised nearly $100bn globally — the highest level in more than a decade. Markets appear to have largely ignored growing tensions between the US and China. Lex thinks US actions against Chinese companies could backfire.

Some of the most dramatic fundraisings and price moves are taking place in Shanghai, where a surge of listings has pushed the city’s one-year-old Nasdaq-style Star market to the world’s number two venue for new listings.

The initial public offering of Ant Group is expected to raise $30bn. It will be the  biggest of the year — perhaps of all time — and could soon give Star market the top spot. The Chinese fintech company controlled by Alibaba founder Jack Ma should remain one of the stocks best able to keep returns positive even in the case of a market backlash.

Other Chinese tech companies, including social media group Tencent, have proved resilient. President Donald Trump’s executive order against Tencent’s popular social network service WeChat has not been able to dent a 44 per cent rally this year. Limiting US company access to WeChat could cause more disruption to US companies than Tencent’s earnings.

Within the tech sector, ecommerce has been an investor favourite as the pandemic drives shoppers online. In the UK, the listing of Manchester-based The Hut Group has benefited from the trend. Boss Matt Moulding expects the IPO to create more millionaires than any listing in British corporate history. He may be right. Lex expects there to be more than enough demand to ensure a successful float.

Online shopping is getting a boost in Dubai too. Sales on InstaShop, a local ecommerce site, is growing rapidly. Gross merchandise value — the total paid for goods bought over the app — rose 330 per cent in the second quarter.

Shareholders are not the only ones interested in buying growth. Germany’s food delivery company Delivery Hero has snapped up InstaShop for $360m. Its valuation at just over one times GMV compares favourably with peers. But Lex warns GMV is a slippery metric. The risks of paying up for a cut-throat business with often punitive customer acquisition costs are high.

Even in frenzied times, not all listings are sure hits. Founders of US data mining software company Palantir Technologies claim it is different from the rest of Big Tech. But its business resembles most other software companies that go public these days, complete with big losses driven by sales and marketing expenses. Annual revenues are still below $1bn, after nearly two decades in business. The hype may exceed its real breadth and scale.

For conservative investors who want to steer clear of volatile tech stocks, stable high dividend stocks have been the preferred choice. That once-reliable flow of payouts may not stick around for long. Most European companies have cut or cancelled their dividends. They are down about 40 per cent overall. 

As overstretched companies seize the opportunity provided by the pandemic to reset expectations, Lex suggests investors readjust their own: an “attractive” yield, once 5 per cent, is now more like 3 per cent.

Long term, returns from US and UK companies could be held back by measures taken to address the crisis. Lex’s deep dive explains why the wave of bankruptcies some people expected has not occurred. But a host of zombie companies whose operating profits do not cover interest costs have appeared. Returns are likely to remain depressed. US and UK-listed companies raised unprecedented amounts to stay afloat. But there is a cost to pay.

Still, the global retail investing frenzy shows no signs of abating. In China, regulators are encouraging it. ChiNext, Shenzhen’s Nasdaq rival, has doubled its daily trading limits to 20 per cent each way. In the US, the Securities and Exchange Commission wants more investors to have broader investment access. Plenty of chances for you to make your fortunes.

Enjoy your weekend,

June Yoon
Lex writer

Dear readers,

I made a couple of mistakes the first time I visited San Francisco, as a gauche 21-year-old in 1985. The first was to check into an alarming motel of a kind that would later feature in movies such as Pulp Fiction and No Country for Old Men. The second was not to stick around, become a venture capitalist and wait for the start-ups to mushroom.

Back then, Silicon Valley was still more about microprocessors than their sophisticated use. Biotech had a glamour computing lacked. Businesses such as Google and Facebook were not even glints in their founders’ eyes. Now they are large, maturing businesses and therefore the subject of angry public debate.

The Federal Trade Commission is guilty of a failure of foresight of its own here. It has demanded information from five tech giants about smaller acquisitions over the past 10 years. It is worried some of these takeovers squashed competition. Well, thank you for finally noticing, FTC.

When disrupters become incumbents, they have an obvious motive to forestall disruption of their own business models. Selling out to a tech giant has therefore been the easiest exit route for founders of small start-ups since the early noughties.

Why has the FTC suddenly got religion? It must be rattled by growing calls in the US to break up companies such as Alphabet, Facebook and Amazon. A local conspiracy theory also holds that tougher regulation of tech groups under President Donald Trump is intended to deny political capital to Democratic rivals in an election year.

The broader issue is that competition policy is dysfunctional on both sides of the Atlantic, particularly when confronted by big tech. The historic mission of regulators is to keep prices down for customers. That blinds them to rents extracted in personal data rather than money. Large takeovers are the main trigger for antitrust scrutiny. They have few powers to resist dominance that depends on network effects.

Competition policy is only one arena where hostility to big tech has been unleashed. Another is employment regulation.

Here in California, a district judge has just denied businesses dependent on gig workers a temporary reprieve from a new law. The legislation broadens the classification of employees, who get many benefits contractors forfeit.

Uber is pursuing a multipronged defensive strategy. Legal appeals aside, it has been trialling a rejigged version of its app intended to circumvent the crackdown. Alongside rival  Lyft, the ride-hailing company may also seek a ballot of Californians that would give gig employers an exemption.

About 450,000 residents of California are  gig workers. Tech groups such as Uber say they benefit from the flexibility denied to such wage slaves as Silicon Valley executives. Set against that is low pay and a lack of job security.

Buzzing round San Francisco in Uber and Lyft vehicles, Lex was left pondering the financial advantages to customers. Many new economy services are provided at below cost price. What kind of subsidy are investors giving customers? There is a certain satisfaction in free riding, even if only one part of your trip merits that description.

The reporting standards of tech groups are patchy. Moreover, Uber now boasts that it makes an adjusted ebitda profit on its worldwide rides business. This works out to about 75 cents per trip. Apply similar metrics to Lyft, which is losing money, and you get to a subsidy of about $1 per journey.

Uber Eats, the food delivery arm of Uber, is also in the red. The implicit subsidy for a meal for two costing about $25 would be a couple of dollars, judging from recently published accounts.

Similar calculations suggest backers are paying subscribers an estimated 10 cents a day to watch Netflix’s curious mix of dramas featuring royals, drug dealers and supernatural entities.

Naturally, businesses such as these imagine they are building valuable franchises. Some doubtless are. Others are just burning piles of cash. The skill of investors lies in working out which is which. “Being too early is just another way of going bankrupt,” remarks one local venture capitalist. Perhaps I should not beat myself up for failing to spot a tech revolution was brewing on that first trip to the West Coast.

Enjoy the rest of your week.

Jonathan Guthrie
Head of Lex

Dear readers,

The global backlash against Big Tech is not all bad news for Silicon Valley. For some, the techlash is proving to be an irresistibly effective marketing ploy. 

Earlier this week, news website Axios reported that Snap founder and chief executive Evan Spiegel had appeared on stage in Germany and taken a swipe at Facebook (which has plundered Snapchat features in the past) by claiming that his social media platform had avoided the criticisms levelled at Facebook because it adopted the right division between private and public communication. In the past he has pointed to differences in data privacy too. 

This is only partly true. Snapchat did mark itself as a different kind of social media company by encouraging users to send messages that disappeared. However the other, less noble, reason it has not been hauled up in front of lawmakers in Washington is because it is a much smaller company. With daily active users hovering at about 210m it has a fraction of the clout Facebook wields  via its 1.6bn users. 

But Snap is not alone in seeing an opportunity in anti-tech sentiment. Apple has paid for billboards crowing about its privacy policies. Sonos is suing Google, accusing it of copying speaker technology, and was invited to Washington to talk about its experiences. 

All three are capitalising on the growing public unease felt towards companies like Google, Facebook and Amazon and the impact that they have on democracy, privacy and society in general. 

Criticising tech has gone mainstream. Both major political parties in the US berate the industry — albeit for different reasons. At the World Economic Forum in Davos last year, George Soros queried its power. Regulators round the world have launched investigations and fines. Multiple journalists have published articles in which they try to ‘break up’ with their smartphone or Amazon account or Google search engine dependency. Earlier this month, online magazine Slate published a list of the 30 ‘ most evil’ tech companies in which it claimed that the era of enchantment with Silicon Valley was over. Every major tech company was included. Amazon was number one. 

Pinpointing the start date of the techlash is tricky. Some suggest February 2017, when former Uber employee Susan Fowler wrote a widely shared blog post about her troubling experiences at the company. Or March 2018, when it was revealed that Cambridge Analytica tried to influence elections via Facebook user data.

Both seemed to spur political willingness to pick a fight with the industry. But the failure of the Arab spring had already silenced those who claimed social media would connect the world and spread democracy. Sean Parker’s much mocked 2013 Lord of the Rings-ish wedding in Big Sur was used as proof that Silicon Valley’s elite could be as obnoxious as any other industry. 

Either way it now feels firmly rooted. So the most jarring aspect of the techlash is that it has not yet been terrible for business. Facebook shares rose when it received a record $5bn fine for privacy violations as investors registered relief that it had not been worse. Europe’s General Data Protection Regulation went into effect in 2018 and has made no discernible impact to Google or Facebook. Uber has vowed to battle against a new California law that gives gig economy workers more benefits. 

Action has been piecemeal and investigations take years. Even if decisions are taken, Microsoft has proved that a company need not break up just because it is told to. The industry’s reputation may have undergone irreparable damage but its businesses are doing just fine. 

Enjoy the rest of your week.

Elaine Moore
Deputy editor of Lex

INTERSERVE 72.50 P 70 67.50 15 Aug 59.50 65 62.50 60 9 Aug 10 Aug 13 Aug 14 Aug 15 Aug Support services and construction companies have not had the best time of late, but Interserve offered "crumbs of comfort" in first-half results, say analysts at Liberum. Guidance on the energy-from-waste business "seemed on track", while the debt pile was slightly lower than expected. Meanwhile, the prospect of buyers sniffing around makes the shares look cheap. However, equity remains "a small number between two big ones", they add, with a big enterprise value and net debt of £645m.

"Significant risks" justify a reduced target price of 65p, from 90p, and a "hold" rating.

If Amazon buying Whole Foods was a warning sign, Alibaba's partnership with US supermarket Kroger this week shows that the online grocery battle is no phony war. So what does this mean for Ocado - fresh from its own Kroger partnership? Nothing yet, say analysts at Peel Hunt, who retain their "buy" rating and a target price of 1,700p. Ocado would be unlikely to give exclusivity in the massive Chinese market to Kroger. Indeed, an Alibaba tie-up for the FTSE 100 grocery logistics firm could be a way into China, where the online grocery market is set to more than double by 2020.

9 Aug 10 Aug 13 Aug 14 Aug 15 Aug Paddy Power Betfair is the old favourite on a bit of slow going. In the short term the business has faced disruption far greater than anyone expected, say analysts at Barclays. A big tech integration following the bookmakers' merger, regulation in the UK and Australia and an online gambling slowdown are the driving factors behind a price target downgrade, from 91p to 77.3p. However, the stock is still a good bet for the longer term, Barclays says, giving an "overweight" rating. A geographical mix and a strong online presence should see it come out quids in in the end.

urn:contentItem:5SV9-W8D1-JCMN-Y249-00000-00Best Reads for Casual Friday: Big Tech Businesses Gets Political2018-07-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:20:51ZLexisNexisBest Reads for Casual Friday: Big Tech Businesses Gets PoliticalDavid Holley

Jul 20, 2018( Xconomy: http://www.xconomy.com/ Delivered by Newstex) You've made it to Friday. Time to curl up in your cubicle, pop open one of these in-depth, entertaining reads, and catch up on some of what you missed during a busy week.This week we're taking a look at all the political stories that are coming out of the tech world. And given the current political environment, there's a cornucopia from which to choose. Enjoy.How to Combat China's Rise in Tech: Federal Spending, Not Tariffs[1] —The New York Times Make love, not tariffs.

(Did I just repeat the NYT's headline joke? Hm.) A thoughtful column on why more government planning and investment in technology, like China has been doing, might actually be a better course of action for the U.S. than starting a trade war.On a Big Story Like the Helsinki Trump/Putin Summit, Google News' Algorithm Isn't Up to the Task[2] —NiemanLab Let's say you wanted to get up to speed on what actually went down with Trump and Putin. If you looked on Google for the top articles, like they did at Nieman, you got one primary source: Fox News.E.U. Slaps $5B Antitrust Fine on Google; Trump Blasts Back With Tweet[3] —Xconomy President Trump doesn't take the big antitrust[4] fine against Google kindly, and sends the E.U. a message—via his favorite communication platformZuckerberg: The Recode Interview[5] and Congratulations, Mr. President: Zuckerberg Secretly Called Trump After The Election[6] —Recode —BuzzFeed News First, it's a sprawling, must-read interview with Mark Zuckerberg on how he views Facebook's handling (or mishandling) of its content, including Holocaust deniers and information said to inciteviolence[7], and basically everything else—that is, except diversity[8]. (His comments about the Holocaust caused him to later clarify[9] his intent, too.) Following that is a report by BuzzFeed News that Zuckerberg called Trump after winning the election and praised the campaign's use of the social media network.The Biggest Spender of Political Ads on Facebook? President Trump[10] —The New York Times Speaking of the 2016 election, President Trump has been the biggest Facebook ad spender since May of this year, spending $274,000 on digital campaigns. Advertisements purchased by Trump and his poitical action committee have reportedly gotten 37 million views during that stretch.New York City Looks to Crack Down on Airbnb Amid Housing Crisis[11] —The New York Times The New York City Council passes legislation that would require Airbnb and HomeAway hosts share additional information with a city enforcement agency, in hopes of better regulating the costly temporary rental economy there.Uber Faces Federal Investigation Over Alleged Gender Discrimination[12] —The Wall Street Journal 'Uber Technologies Inc. is being investigated by the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission after a complaint about gender inequity,' The Journal reports.New Ethics Code Urges Tech Firms and Coders To Avoid Harming Society[13] —Xconomy Do no harm, and other gems, now finally apply to tech firms!Health Insurers Are Vacuuming Up Details About You — And It Could Raise Your Rates[14] —ProPublica and NPR Got a great rate on your health insurance? No? urn:contentItem:5N4K-B2N1-F00X-J4WV-00000-00Bet on Home Depot, Qualcomm and Two More Big Names to Outperform in March2017-03-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:20:51ZLexisNexisBet on Home Depot, Qualcomm and Two More Big Names to Outperform in MarchJonas Elmerraji

These Rocket Stocks are showing short-term gain catalysts and longer-term growth potential.

The past six months have been high time for stock market investors--since September, the S&P 500 has managed to muscle its way more than 11% higher.

More importantly, there's been almost universal participation from the individual stocks. More than 80% of the individual names in the S&P 500 are up over the course of that six-month stretch.

But don't mistake this environment for a market where you can just buy stocks blindly and still make money. Stock picking still matters a lot in 2017.

Delve a little deeper into the stats, and the gap between outperformers and underperformers becomes a little clearer. For instance, of the stocks that are up in the past six months, nearly half are up 20% or more during that timeframe--in other words, owning leaders means a huge margin of outperformance versus owning the typical stock in the S&P.

So, to find the next set of stocks likely to lead, we're turning to a fresh set of "Rocket Stocks" worth buying for gains ...

In case you're not familiar, Rocket Stocks are our list of companies with short-term gain catalysts and longer-term growth potential. To find them, I run a weekly quantitative screen that seeks out stocks with a combination of analyst upgrades and positive earnings surprises to identify rising analyst expectations, a bullish signal for stocks in any market. After all, where analysts' expectations are increasing, institutional cash often follows. In the past 391 weeks, our weekly list of plays has outperformed the S&P 500's record-breaking run by 77.06%.

So, without further ado, here's a look at this week's Rocket Stocks.


Home Depot

2017 is panning out to be a strong year for shares of home improvement retailer Home Depot Inc. . Just year-to-date, this retailer has handed investors total returns of 12.25%--zoom out to the past six months, and that rally expands to nearly 20% returns. The good news for investors is that Home Depot's price momentum isn't showing any signs of slowing here. Shares hit new all-time highs during this past Friday's trading session.

Home Depot is the biggest home improvement store chain in the world, with 2,278 big box store locations spread across the U.S., Canada, and Mexico. Rising home prices have been a major tailwind for Home Depot--as homeowners feel the wealth effect from their rising equity values, they're becoming increasingly willing to spend more money on home upgrades.

The firm has shifted its attention away from solely DIY customers in the past few years, including pro customers in its target market to take advantage of the growth in the commercial construction market. At the same time, those deeper relationships with contractors are giving it an edge in its service offerings--Home Depot can pair consumers off with service providers who use only Home Depot-supplied products, and collect a markup in the process. Tailwinds in services and an increasing focus on the private label should provide fatter margins for Home Depot in 2017.


Qualcomm Inc.

Despite a shaky start in 2017, Qualcomm Inc. is finding its footing. Since bottoming at the start of February, Qualcomm has been in "rebound mode," charging more than 8% higher, versus a 3.7% upside move in the rest of the S&P 500 over that same timeframe. Clearing black clouds could fuel more upside in Qualcomm as we dig deeper into the calendar year ...

Qualcomm makes chips used in mobile devices. The firm's processors can be found in a number of high-end smartphones, and its components are ubiquitous in the industry (Qualcomm provides the radio modems used in many of the new iPhone 7, for instance). Simply put, if you own a smartphone, there's a very good chance that Qualcomm got paid somewhere along the way. That's not just true if your phone has Qualcomm hardware in it--the firm also owns a massive intellectual property portfolio, licensing its patents and collecting royalties for pretty much every 3G and 4G LTE device that's sold worldwide today.

While anti-competitive concerns surrounding that valuable IP have gotten Qualcomm in hot water with South Korean and Chinese regulators, and patent drama with corporate "frenemies" like Apple Inc. have added to this stock's headline risk, it doesn't change the big picture here. As those black clouds clear, this stock is well-positioned to make up for lost time in 2017. Analyst sentiment is ticking higher in Qualcomm, so we're betting on shares this week ...


Cognizant Technology Solutions Corp.

IT services consultancy Cognizant Technology Solutions Corp. is benefiting from overall growth in the IT services industry. That positioning has translated into a growth rate deep into the double-digits over the past five years, and as more companies look to push more of their IT infrastructure to "the cloud," consulting organizations like Cognizant are well-positioned to see engagements rise.

Cognizant originally made its mark on the business world by acting like a major cost-cutter. The firm was one of the first major IT outsourcers that found success moving technical tasks to India, where a large population of skilled tech workers is able to service accounts at much lower costs than a company could expect to find here at home. Now, the trend toward cost savings as a function of physical infrastructure gives Cognizant the opportunity to leverage its substantial footprint in the U.S. and Europe.

Even though many of Cognizant's professional services providers are based in India, the firm's management and sales team are U.S.-based, giving it a model that continues to sell well here. While the outsourcing model may have lost some of its political appeal, Cognizant actually stands as a possible net winner as companies look to Cognizant to replace H-1B visa positions they have to give up.

Historically, Cognizant's customer base has been incredibly sticky. In other words, switching costs are high and Cognizant's ability to quantify the benefits it offers clients keep retention levels extremely high. Buyers are clearly in control of the price action in this big tech services stock right now ...


Paychex Inc.

Rounding out our list of Rocket Stocks for this week is $22.6 billion payroll company Paychex Inc. . With all of the focus on rising interest rates in the last week, Paychex is a smart way to play the moves from the Fed. More on that in a moment ...

First, Paychex's core business: Paychex provides payroll services for more than 590,000 customers, primarily small and medium-sized businesses. The firm helps those smaller firms navigate the maze of tax and compliance issues involved in paying employees, earning profits in the process. The firm also offers other outsourced HR functions, including 401(k) administration and worker's comp insurance.

Improvements in jobs numbers are a good thing for Paychex--the firm's pricing is generally based on a flat fee plus an addition charge for every employee processed through the platform on payday. More jobs in the economy directly mean more profits at Paychex.

As I mentioned a moment ago, deep down, Paychex is really an interest rate play. That's because the company has historically earned a substantial income from float interest (the interest money it earns on massive payroll accounts between the time that employers deposit funds and employees cash their checks). With rates held near zero for the better part of the last decade, that revenue stream has dried up. A trend back in the direction of higher rates could return an important source of revenue that heads straight to PAYX's bottom line. Investors get their next update on Paychex's business when the firm reports third quarter earnings at the end of this month.
